# Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) – Intermodulation Distortion

# Calculating Intermodulation Products:

To determine the various cross products of two interfering signals the following formulas can be used. Given that one frequency is designated A and the other B, the formulas we apply are:

Fundamental: A; B $1^{st}$

2nd A $\pm$ B

A ± 5B; $2A \pm 4B$; $3A \pm 3B$; $4A \pm 2B$; $5A \pm B$

A $\pm$ 6B; $2A \pm 5B$; $3A \pm 4B$; $4A \pm 3B$; $5A \pm 2B$; $6A \pm B$

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page10' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第10页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) – Intermodulation Distortion

Example: Let $f_{1} = 105.5$ MHz, $f_{2} = 89.5$ MHz (both in FM band)

cross products = $mf_{1} \pm nf_{2}$;

For m=1 and n=1, cross products = 16 MHz, 195 MHz

No problem

For m=2 and n=1, cross products = 121.5 MHz, 300.5 MHz

Problem! The frequency 121.5 MHz is a protected international civilian and military aeronautical emergency frequency!

Interference on this frequency is only permitted at extremely low levels.

# Receiver Selectivity

Selectivity – the ability of a receiver to allow a certain band of frequencies to enter and reject all others.

Selectivity is often measured at -3 dB and – 60 dB of attenuation

![](images/4c8792af1bea74a9a3d6193991591ab15ee25e9f1610e8ec4fb36487c16e8e7d_37.jpg){width=37%}

shape factor = $BW_{60dB}$

$BW_{3dB}$

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page12' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第12页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Receiver Selectivity

Shape Factor = $SF = BW_{-60dB} / BW_{-3dB}$ (ideally = 1)

e.g. for AM, $BW_{-60dB} = 20$ kHz, $BW_{-3dB} = 10$ kHz, SF=2

The lower the SF, the better the selectivity a receiver will have.

More sources of interference can be rejected, such as:

Harmonic distortionIntermodulation distortionAdjacent channel interference

# Receiver Sensitivity

Sensitivity – the minimum RF signal level that can be detected and still produce a "useable" demodulated information signal.

Sensitivity is a receiver specification usually stated in $\mu$V or dBm.

Sensitivity depends on many factors, including

Noise power present at Rx input

Rx's noise figure: (S/N)_{in} / (S/N)_{out}

Sensitivity can be improved by

reducing the temperature of the Rx reducing the bandwidth of the Rx Improving the Rx noise figure

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page14' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第14页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Receiver Sensitivity

The sensitivity of a receiver (in dBm):

S = -174 dBm + NF + 10log(BW) + (desired S/N)

The -174 dBm is the thermal noise power at room temperature (290 K) in a 1 Hz bandwidth (BW)

A receiver's NF (noise figure) = $10 \log$ ((S/N)$_{\text{in}}$ / (S/N)$_{\text{out}}$)

10log(BW) represents the change in noise power due to increasing the bandwidth above 1 Hz. As BW increases, so does noise power.

A receiver's noise floor is the sum of all the noise sources and unwanted signals within it.

S/N is the desired signal-to-noise ratio in dB. Normally, only signals above the noise floor can be processed by a receiver.

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page15' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第15页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Example

Consider a receiver that has a 1 MHz bandwidth and a 20 dB noise figure. If a S/N of 10 dB is desired, the sensitivity (S) is:

S = -174 + 20 + $10\log_{10}1,000,000 + 10$

S = -84 dBm

It can be seen from this that if a lower S/N is required, better receiver sensitivity is necessary.

If a 0 dB S/N is used, the sensitivity would become -94 dBm. The -94 dBm figure is the level at which the signal power equals noise power in the receiver's bandwidth.

# Receiver Desensitization Interference

Receiver desensitization interference occurs when an undesired signal from a nearby "off-frequency" transmitter (usually an adjacent channel) is sufficiently close to a Rx's operating frequency.

The RF selectivity may not be sufficient to block this interference.

![](images/f34ec428daef5f1efe0953f253ad1cea79f7a5557bf9001649e641dde730c0e7_72.jpg){width=72%}

<br><span class='markdown-page-line'>---------------------------------------------<span id='page17' class='markdown-page-text'>[ 第17页 ]</span>---------------------------------------------</span><br><br>

# Receiver Desensitization Interference

If the undesired RF signal is of sufficient amplitude, it will degrade the performance of the Receiver at its operating frequency.

It will have the effect of raising the receiver's sensitivity and reducing the effective coverage of the radio system.
